By MICHEL STEVEN KRUG
The offices of The Dean of Students and Director of
Student Activities has recently formulated a "room use"
Policy proposal which critics allege could limit the
availability of campus resources to unpopular, or poor,
Homewood community organizations. Chris Colombo,
Director of Student Activities, said the proposal was
started in the summer of 1975 at the request of Jakie
Hall, Dean of Students, because "when I first came here,
the problem people complained about was room
reservations," Colombo said.
The fifteen member JHU Union Board, comprised of
undergraduates, graduate students, faculty members,staff
members, and the Union Director, was assigned to discuss,
amend and finally endorse the proposal. The "room use"
Policy defines regulations for sponsoring organizations,
kinds of sponsorship, and fees for sponsorship. "This
Policy was developed to give more space to University
organizations. We can't be in the business of giving free
Space," Colombo said.
University organizations can book such facilities as
Shriver Hall, the Glass Pavilion, the Great Hall, the
Listening and Viewing Room, free of charge "if it is a
regular program on the lecture schedule," according to
Colombo. If a non-University group expresses interest in
holding an event of general interest n campus, and a
University group wishes to co-sponsor, oom fees will be
Split. The university organization's half of the fee will be
waived, while the co-sponsor must pay their half of the
rental fee. Sponsorship by a non-University organization
must be payed in full, booked six months prior to the
date of the event, and approved by the Director of
Student Activities. Space is granted on a first come first
serve basis, regardless of the political affiliation of the
organization, Colombo said. Asked whether any
non-University organizations had yet been denied room
use privileges, Colombo said he was not aware of any such
cases.
But Ralph Moore, a member of the Chaplain's Office,
Objects that the proposal to charge non-university
organizations one half the rental rate for co-sponsored
events could price economically deficient organizations
from the market. He says it's a form of "economic,
discrimination" for private groups like the People's Free
Medical Clinic, Committee for the Conversion of the
Applied Physics Lab, the food co-op, and the Baltimore
Experimental High School. Though he agrees the
university's first obligation is to its own community,

Moore says the proposal could isolate Hopkins students
from the community at large, by curtailing non-university
organization benefits. Colombo responds that local
residents are already urged to participate in the Spring
Fair, Sunday Experience lecture series, guest lectures,
and films.
Flo Leibowitz, a graduate student member of the
Union Board, makes stronger allegations. "They claim
there's no room, that they.re already booked solid for
charitable events. But I've passed empty rooms many
times in the week. The whole policy seems to be directed
against politically controversial groups. It seems to say if
you can pay, you can use whatever you want, but I think
the university is trying to avoid any connection with
unpopular organizations. It's circumstantial evidence, but
it's very strong."

Leibowitz proposed an amendment on the following
portion (so-called A-3) of the room reservation policy
which she said was too "broad and vague" and could be
arbitrarily applied by university officials: "When it
becomes apparent that certain activities, because of their
very nature, place the university in a position where it
cannot exercise its proprietal responsibility in insuring
compliance with civil Jaw, then said activity cannot
legitimately function on campus." Her amendment drawn
up by a lawyer reads as follows: "Nothing in these
regulations shall be construed as limiting the university
from exercising its inherent right and respnsibility to
insure compliance with the laws of the United States, the
State of Maryland and the City of Baltimore."No vote
has been taken by the Union Board on this amendment to
date.
The graduate student further alleges the broad wording
of A-3 allows the administration to harrass the Hopkins
Gay Caucus Alliance. University officials singled out the
Gay Caucus by forcing them to register their guests at
their autumn dance, she said. Colombo, however, said
"the university never questioned the existence of that
group. Hopkins requires registration at all dances and at
the Rathskellar, he added. "We're not trying to ruin
people's lives." But if the organization breaks the
proprietal responsibility of Hopkins to uphold the law,
the group, any group, will not be allowed to use the
room again."
Michael Liss, Chairman of the Union Board said the
problem with Gay Caucus dances is that "90% of the
people" are from the outside. "The first couple were well.
behaved. The Union managers did complain that the last
dance got a little. rowdy." No evidence of illegality is
known. But Leibowitz said "it's a question of making so
many requirements. It's asking alot for those people to
put their name on paper."
The Union Board will reconsider the "room use"
proposal during their next session before the end of the
semester. The Student Council and Academic Council
first must endorse the proposal before the university's
general counsel incorporates it as part of the Hopkins
rental contract.

By BOB RIGGS
Two people, including a Johns Hopkins student, were
knifed and three arrests were made Friday night in a series
of campus incidents connected with the spring fair,
according to Johns Hopkins Security Manager Robert
Larkin.
The student, a freshman, was slashed around 9:46 pm
near the Haunted House amusement van in front of the
new dormitories. He gave the following account.
"A friend and I were going to a movie. There was a
group of: kids standing there in front of the Haunted
House. One of them was cussing, and another said
something about me beating up their girlfriend. Two of
them started to push me, and a fight broke out between
the three of us.

hospital."
The victim was taken to Union Memorial Hospital

By AL DANIELS
With highly touted Widener losing to Ursinus this past
Saturday, the Jays have but to beat Swarthmore in a
twinbill, postponed by rain until May, to win an NCAA
playoff berth.
With everyone on the team taking the spotlight at one
time or another, their charge towards their present 13-4
record (7-1 in the MAC) went as follows this past week.
The Orioles were fighting the rain in Detroit rock city;
there were no birds as we passed through Graceham but
for sure the baseball Blue Jays were in Chestertown last
Saturday to take two from the Shoremen of Washington
College, 3-2 and 7-4.
First though let's get them on the bus. They weren't
quite ready to board last Tuesday as they swept their 4th
and 5th of 8 straight with the victim being the U. of Md.
Eastern Shore Hawks,6-5 and 2-0.
Bob Babb, who stole four bases on the day, knocked in
Steve Galloway, of bench jockeying fame, with the
winning run.
Frank Parreira ended his complete game win by striking
out a guy who got a triple off him two innings earlier on a
tough curve ball. Frank, however, was the victim three
nights later when he was on the the receiving end of a
switchblade attack during Spring Fair. Despite 30 stitches,
Parreira was able to play at Washington College and
performed well.
After four consecutive one-run victories, the Jays gave
Jason Sussman a bit more leeway in the second game, but
just barely so. For the JH kids, 3rd batter Emala was
clutch in knocking in the winning run of the 2nd UMES
game. Em plated Babb and rightfielder John Santo was
sent across with an insurance run as Lewing slugged a
double that was almost out of the park. Dave earned
national distinction by placing 3rd among all power
hitters with three home runs in the team's 1st S games, all
hit on the road. Commenting on the spaciousness of the

Jays' home field leftfielder Lewing said "it would take a
cannon to get one out of here." There's always plenty of
room for hits to fall in though.
On the mound for the Hop, Jason Sussman twirled a
5-hitter whiffing nine and walking none. The team played
crucial errorless ball behind him, as they have for all their
shutouts, and was almost ready to roll.
Thursday JHU beat rival Loyola by a score of 7-4, the
first Hopkins sports team to beat our Charles St. rivals
this year.
Hurlers Charlie Lachenbruch, who only hielded 3 hits
and 1 earned run in 6 innings, and winning reliever
Steffan "Junk-Balling" Burns starred.
The hero, however, was Mike April who knocked the
winning run in with two outs in the 8th on a clutch
double. "Little Wootten" has been a consistent star in
centerfield as well, as at the plate.
Besides keeping the winning streak intact, the
doubleheader win at Washington catapulted the Jays into

first place in their division of the MAC.
The Santo brothers Michael John and John Michael
•found a good number of fans in the bleachers: a little of

day and collect extra base hits. Lewing smacks one
completely out of the ball park.

of smarts.
Eight in a row.- Longest winning streak by any JHU
team, except for the classy fencing squad. Parreira is
forced out of the twinbill late in the 2nd game with a bee
sting;it wasn't his greatest weekend.

Big Blue steamrolls Brown as Huntley stars
By ANDREW COHEN
While many of us '.ere sampling the ethnic foods,
lounging in the quad plistening to the super sounds, trying
our own luck at the wheel of fortune, or just plain
enjoying the insurgance of new life that had been brought
to the Hopkins campus by the Spring Fair, the Blue Jay
Varsity Lacrosse team was finding new life of its own
after last week's disappointing loss by whipping the
Bruins of Brown University, 17-8, on Homewood Field
Saturday afternoon.
Over 4200 spectators sitting under heavily overcast
skies witnessed the Jays combine a well balanced scoring
attack, led by sophomore midfielder Dave Huntley with
four goals and one assist, with a strong defense, led by
freshman defender Mark Greenberg and a sparkling Kevin
Mahon, senior tri-captain, in goal. There had been a
question as to how well)the team would perform in those
areas due to the injunesIsuffered by middle Tom Myrick
(twisted knee, out until Maryland game) last week at
Cornell and lettering defenseman Mike Sheedy (twisted
ankle, out until Navy game) before Saturday's contest in
the warm-up, but these fears were!quickly laid to rest.
The Hopkins' lax men answered all questions, though,
within the first few minutes of the game. Off the face off,
the Bruins took control and paraded through Jay territory
for a full two minutes. Fine checking by Greenberg and
frosh starter Leroy Katz kept the opponents from getting
off any appreciable shot. Instead, Greenberg stole the ball
and spearheaded a drive that led to a goal by sophomore
Frank Cutrone, aided by one of Rich Hirsch's three assists
for the game. Seconds later at 3:17 of the first quarter,
midfielder Phil Frederico, off a feed from sophomore Bob
Teasdall, fired a shot that Bruin goalie Rich Gittleman
initially stopped, but allowed to tricklein off his stick for
the Blue Jay 2-0 lead:
The third ranked Jays increased their first quarter lead
to 4 and 0 when with 3:59 left senior George Johnson
rifled home a goal of a nifty pass from leading scorer Mike
O'Neill (2 goals, 2 assists in this game) and minutes later
middle Bob Desimone picked off an errant Bruin pass in
his own end and took the ball all the way downfield
before passing off to Huntley who slammed it in.
The Bruin's somewhat sloppy offense finally got in gear
in the second quarter when their star attaclunan freshman

Rich Handelman fed middie Jack Lawrence who pumped
it in, ten feet out on the left side of the net.
Hopkins answered back with two more goals, a Huntley
to Hirsch combo at 4:54 and an O'Neill unassisted break
away with 8:19 left. Bruin attackman Rich Care11 added
the final tally of the first half when he slapped a loose ball
in from in front of the Jay net. It seemed that the potent
Blue Jay offense was too much for Gittleman and
company as they took 28 Jay shots while mustering only
15 of their own.
Off the second half face, DeSimone took the ball right
on goal. His shot was kicked out by the Brown net
minder, but O'Neill scooped up the rebound and crossfed
Huntley for the score.
Brown continued to struggle back as Handelman gave a
strong individual effort in circling the Jay net before
firing an off balanced shot past Mahon. The goal didn't
disturb Chic's boys as they flew right back in scoring
three consecutive goals, one by Teasdall at 5:09 of the
third quarter, one by O'Neill at 7:40, and one by
sophomore midfielder Joe Garavente at 8:33. At this
point coach Henry Ciccarone replaced Mahon with junior

goalie Jay Trainor.
Closing the third quarter and beginning the fourth, the
Jays began to relive shades of Cornell a week ago, as the
Bruins piled in three unanswered goals by midfielders
John Grill and Dennis Longpre, and Handelman. With
about 12 minutes left in the contest, the Jays held a 10-6
lead.
They were not about to go through last week's
3xperience again, though, and the Jays began to pour it
on. By game's end the Blue Jays had outscored the Bruins
7-2 with goals; two a piece from Huntley and frosh Jon
Swerdloff, and one a piece from Garavente,junior Doober
Auburn, and sophomore Scott Baugher. Handelman and
Care11 dumped in the final goals for the Bruins and the
Jays won 17-8.. Overall, the Jays had outshot the Bruins
of Brown 55-32.
"We were a bit disheartened over last week's loss," said
the coach, "but we played well against a somewhat flat
Brown who did hang in well."
The Jays now travel to West Point to play Army,
before facing off with Navy in two weeks at Homewood.

With highly touted Widener losing to Ursinus this past
Saturday, the Jays have but to beat Swarthmore in a
twinbill, postponed by rain until May, to win an NCAA
playoff berth.
With everyone on the team taking the spotlight at one
time or another, their charge towards their present 13-4
record (7-1 in the MAC) went as follows this past week.
The Orioles were fighting the rain in Detroit rock city;
there were no birds as we passed through Graceham but
for sure the baseball Blue Jays were in Chestertown last
Saturday to take two from the Shoremen of Washington
College, 3-2 and 7-4.

quite ready to board last Tuesday as they swept their 4th
and 5th of 8 straight with the victim being the U. of Md.
Eastern Shore Hawks,6-5 and 2-0.
Bob Babb, who stole four bases on the day, knocked in
Steve Galloway, of bench jockeying fame, with the
winning run.
Frank Parreira ended his complete game win by striking
out a guy who got a triple off him two innings earlier on a
tough curve ball. Frank, however, was the victim three
nights later when he was on the the receiving end of a
switchblade attack during Spring Fair. Despite 30 stitches,
Parreira was able to play at Washington College and
performed well.

Jason Sussman a bit more leeway in the second game, but

clutch in knocking in the winning run of the 2nd UMES
game. Em plated Babb and rightfielder John Santo was
sent across with an insurance run as Lewing slugged a
double that was almost out of the park. Dave earned
national distinction by placing 3rd among all power
hitters with three home runs in the team's 1st S games, all

Jays' home field leftfielder Lewing said "it would take a

double. "Little Wootten" has been a consistent star in
centerfield as well, as at the plate.

Big Blue steamrolls Brown as Huntley stars
By ANDREW COHEN
While many of us '.ere sampling the ethnic foods,
lounging in the quad plistening to the super sounds, trying
our own luck at the wheel of fortune, or just plain
enjoying the insurgance of new life that had been brought
to the Hopkins campus by the Spring Fair, the Blue Jay
Varsity Lacrosse team was finding new life of its own
after last week's disappointing loss by whipping the
Bruins of Brown University, 17-8, on Homewood Field
Saturday afternoon.
Over 4200 spectators sitting under heavily overcast
skies witnessed the Jays combine a well balanced scoring
attack, led by sophomore midfielder Dave Huntley with
four goals and one assist, with a strong defense, led by
freshman defender Mark Greenberg and a sparkling Kevin
Mahon, senior tri-captain, in goal. There had been a
question as to how well)the team would perform in those
areas due to the injunesIsuffered by middle Tom Myrick
(twisted knee, out until Maryland game) last week at
Cornell and lettering defenseman Mike Sheedy (twisted
ankle, out until Navy game) before Saturday's contest in
the warm-up, but these fears were!quickly laid to rest.
The Hopkins' lax men answered all questions, though,
within the first few minutes of the game. Off the face off,
the Bruins took control and paraded through Jay territory
for a full two minutes. Fine checking by Greenberg and
frosh starter Leroy Katz kept the opponents from getting
off any appreciable shot. Instead, Greenberg stole the ball
and spearheaded a drive that led to a goal by sophomore
Frank Cutrone, aided by one of Rich Hirsch's three assists
for the game. Seconds later at 3:17 of the first quarter,
midfielder Phil Frederico, off a feed from sophomore Bob
Teasdall, fired a shot that Bruin goalie Rich Gittleman
initially stopped, but allowed to tricklein off his stick for
the Blue Jay 2-0 lead:
The third ranked Jays increased their first quarter lead
to 4 and 0 when with 3:59 left senior George Johnson
rifled home a goal of a nifty pass from leading scorer Mike
O'Neill (2 goals, 2 assists in this game) and minutes later
middle Bob Desimone picked off an errant Bruin pass in
his own end and took the ball all the way downfield
before passing off to Huntley who slammed it in.
The Bruin's somewhat sloppy offense finally got in gear
in the second quarter when their star attaclunan freshman

Rich Handelman fed middie Jack Lawrence who pumped
it in, ten feet out on the left side of the net.
Hopkins answered back with two more goals, a Huntley
to Hirsch combo at 4:54 and an O'Neill unassisted break
away with 8:19 left. Bruin attackman Rich Care11 added
the final tally of the first half when he slapped a loose ball
in from in front of the Jay net. It seemed that the potent
Blue Jay offense was too much for Gittleman and
company as they took 28 Jay shots while mustering only
15 of their own.
Off the second half face, DeSimone took the ball right
on goal. His shot was kicked out by the Brown net
minder, but O'Neill scooped up the rebound and crossfed
Huntley for the score.
Brown continued to struggle back as Handelman gave a
strong individual effort in circling the Jay net before
firing an off balanced shot past Mahon. The goal didn't
disturb Chic's boys as they flew right back in scoring
three consecutive goals, one by Teasdall at 5:09 of the
third quarter, one by O'Neill at 7:40, and one by
sophomore midfielder Joe Garavente at 8:33. At this
point coach Henry Ciccarone replaced Mahon with junior

goalie Jay Trainor.
Closing the third quarter and beginning the fourth, the
Jays began to relive shades of Cornell a week ago, as the
Bruins piled in three unanswered goals by midfielders
John Grill and Dennis Longpre, and Handelman. With
about 12 minutes left in the contest, the Jays held a 10-6
lead.
They were not about to go through last week's
3xperience again, though, and the Jays began to pour it
on. By game's end the Blue Jays had outscored the Bruins
7-2 with goals; two a piece from Huntley and frosh Jon
Swerdloff, and one a piece from Garavente,junior Doober
Auburn, and sophomore Scott Baugher. Handelman and
Care11 dumped in the final goals for the Bruins and the
Jays won 17-8.. Overall, the Jays had outshot the Bruins
of Brown 55-32.
"We were a bit disheartened over last week's loss," said
the coach, "but we played well against a somewhat flat
Brown who did hang in well."
The Jays now travel to West Point to play Army,
before facing off with Navy in two weeks at Homewood.
